caption.para: &appshort;'s text label display element provides deceptively simple ways to show text labels. The &ns;::w::label handles multiple colors, fonts, and word-wrapping all by itself. It even automatically updates its appearance when the current display theme changes.

But sometimes even that may not be sufficient. This chapter gives an example of using &appshort;'s internal, low-level text rendering classes and templates to draw a text string with a visible drop shadow. The gray shadow gets rendered by repeatedly drawing the same text string over itself, but slightly adjusting the string's position every time; and finally rendering the topmost layer, in black. This produces a shadow-like effect.

section.title: Font collections
section.para: customfontrenderer.C gives a basic example of using the following classes and templates:

listitem.para: An &ns;::w::fontcollection is a cached object that represents a particular font. An &ns;::w::font gets prepared first, which specifies the font's face, size, and other attributes, then passed to any internal display element implementation object to construct a font collection.

This class is called a &ns;::w::fontcollection because it may represent more than one actual font. Drawn text strings are unicode strings, std::u32string, and it's possible that different system fonts are required for rendering the entire unicode text.

note.para: &ns;::w::fontcollection and &ns;::w::freetypefont operate on a sequence of unicode text by a beginning and an ending iterator. Any container of char32_t, not just a std::u32string works as long as its iterators are at least forward iterators.

listitem.para: An &ns;::w::freetypefont is one individual font in a &ns;::w::fontcollection. The &ns;::w::fontcollection iterates over the unicode string, and computes the &ns;::w::freetypefont for each part of the std::u32string. In nearly all cases, the &ns;::w::fontcollection produces one, lonely &ns;::w::freetypefont for the entire std::u32string; but the customfontrenderer.C examples shows how to deal with multiple &ns;::w::freetypefonts.

Finally, an &ns;::w::composite_text_stream is a helper object that prepares and renders the actual text. Each &ns;::w::freetypefont takes a range of unicode characters that it renders, and places them into a &ns;::w::composite_text_stream. Then, its composite() methods composites the text into a &picture;.

section.para: customfontrenderer.C demonstrates the proper sequence of events for rendering unicode text:

listitem.para: Use the resulting &ns;::w::fontcollection's load_glyphs() method to load the actual glyphs, or characters (if they're not yet cached or loaded already).

Other &ns;::w::fontcollection methods return various other metadata of the loaded glyphs, such as their size. customfontrenderer.C uses them to compute the size of the custom display element, in advance, when creating it. This can be done any time before drawing the actual text, and customfontrenderer.C does this work just once, when creating the custom display element.

Using the same &ns;::w::fontcollection to draw different text requires the new text's glyphs to be loaded; starting the whole process from the beginning. Although it's necessary to load only any new character's glyphs, it's simpler to just pass the entire new string to load_glyphs(), which keeps track of what's been loaded, and quickly skips over previously-loaded glyphs.
Use the &ns;::w::composite_text_stream to render the text into a &picture; buffer.
